text: Cask at Charlies. Clear golden with a small white head. Earthy notes, twigs, dry green plants, golden bread, light citrus and flowers. Light to medium body, low sweetness, medium bitter, long mild dry finish. Fine.
Cask at the Wellington; clear golden yellow pour with a bubbly white head, aroma has a hint of peach, taste also has peach along with some mellow sweet malts, some citrus.
Cask @ The Wharf, Aalborg. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and light hoppy - grass and fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and moderate bitter finish. 110317

Cask @ Christian 4 Tal, Odense. Pours slight unclear golden with a white head and lacings. Very fruity And dry. Good hops and a bit of biscuit. Really harmonic. Big juicy quaffer! Whisper of lemon and citrus.

Cask at Christian Firtal. Slightly hazy golden with a lasting white head. Amazing fruity hoppy aroma with peach, orange and tangerine, a herbal touch and some fine light malt. Fruity flavour with grassy notes, bready and fresh grain malt and that Crouch Vale house character that just hits all the right spots with me. Thank you CV for exporting to Denmark. The tastiest way is Essex

Pours golden with white head. Aroma and taste is citrus fruity aroma and taste, some grassy hoppy goodness, light floral, prominent lemon nuances, crisp pale malts. Nice refreshing.

27th May 2015Colchester Beer Festival at the Colchester Arts Centre. Cask. Almost clear gold beer, small pale cream colour head. Palate is light and smooth with decent fine carbonation. Smooth mildly sweet pale malts. Good hoppy fruits - little orange peel along with sweeter generic fruits. A floral accent comes in before a light finish. Tasty and very drinkable.
From cask. Pours clear and golden yellow with a small white head. Aroma is toasted malty. Light grassy. Bitter, grassy and light citrusy. Dry and slight herbal finish.

Aroma and taste is citrus fruity aroma and taste, some grassy hoppy goodness, light floral, prominent lemon nuances, crisp pale malts, refreshing and highly quaffable brew, whats not to like. Great condition. Lovely.

Cask @ Market Porter, Borough SE1. Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty hoppy grapefruit aroma. Fruity malty hoppy grapefruit flavor. Hasa  slightly sweetish malty grapefruit hoppy finish with some bitterness in the aftertaste.
Handpulled cask at the Lower Red Lion, St. Albans during september. Gold with a white head. Oroma of oranges. Citrus lemon/grapfruit hops. Decent.

Cask conditioned at The Woolpack, Banbury. Pale gold with white head. Ah, the old Goldings hop, perfumey, peachy, hop oily, all the typical Goldings adjectives were used in the Pub last night and yes they were spot on, the pub tasting sessions are getting pretty good. There is a slight sweetness to the beer, quite honeyed which took the edge off the hops for me, but still a pretty decent beer.

On cask at The Rake (Borough).  Slightly hazy gold pour with a small frothy off-white head.  Pungent, slightly sour UK hop (now I’m entering this, I see it’s Styrian Goldings - cool, I thought it was Goldings) funk aroma, with a mild oaty grain backing it adequately.  The taste was quite acidic, but unlike the Dreadnought that preceded it, this one worked for me - enough malt profile to prevent me thinking even remotely that this might be a pint of dishwater.  Light bodied for all that, it had a still, slick, solidly acidic mouthfeel, with a long funky finish.  A good Goldings Golden!

Cask at peterborough beer fest. First beer of the fest! Alround rating: Pale maklts, honey character, orangey and grassy bitterness. Tasty and typical of crouch vale, but lacking the killer citrus hop punch.

(Cask at Market Porter, Southwark, London, 10 Aug 2008) Golden amber colour with frothy, off-white head. Fruity, floral nose with citrussy hops. Fruity, hoppy taste with notes of orange, apricots and citrussy hops in the finish. Balanced sweetness, generous bitterness. Nice beer in the usual Crouch Vale vein.

Cask at Churchil’s, Ramsgate: Bright golden yellow with a thick white head. Aroma is very fruity with plenty of hops. Taste is very similar, lots and lots of fruit and the hops are lovely. Very good pint.

Cask-conditioned at The Wenlock, 1/8/08. Amber coloured with a decent white head. Hoppy aroma with plenty of oranges, apricots and grass. Flavour started with some fruity malt followed by citrus and a long juicy hop finish. Excellent.
